Award.AwardTitle: PIRE: Modeling of Flood Hazards and Geomorphic Impacts of Levee Breach and Dam Failure
Award.AbstractNarration:
0730246
Abstract
Chaudhry

This award provides support for a proposal submitted to the 2007 OISE Partnerships for International Research and Education (PIRE) competition. It involves a collaboration on the US side between the University of South Carolina at Columbia, the University of Puerto Rico, and South Carolina State University with the Catholic University of Louvain in Belgium and the Instituto Superior Tecnico in Lisbon, Portugal.

Intellectual Merit. The collaborative partners propose to conduct research on erosion, deposition, and transport of sediment including the mobilization of the bed following levee or dam failure in a unified manner to provide a complete and accurate picture of resulting flood hazard and the associated geomorphic impacts. A three-dimensional model will be developed to study the geomorphic process produced by highly transient flow. The model will be free of many limitations of existing numerical models by coupling the flow and bed mobilization, solving the non-hydrostatic pressure field, and including the effects of sediment cohesion. The laboratory studies will help to understand and quantify the mechanism of soil erosion and bed movement and mobilization by the flood wave and provide test data for the verification of computer models. The two European partners were selected because of their unique laboratory facilities, technical expertise, experience of senior personnel, and ongoing funded research on the topic. Different experiments will make use of the unique facilities at each of the European labs. The European partners offer the added benefit of being part of a larger European-level project supported by the European Commission (EC).

Broader Impacts. The educational plan includes the exchange of faculty members, graduate and undergraduate students, internationalization of water resources curricula, field visits, and development of postgraduate courses. Each year, 10 undergraduate and 5 graduate students, a research professor, a post-doctoral fellow, and several US and European researchers will participate in the project activities. High school and undergraduate students will be offered summer research opportunities, and female and underrepresented groups will comprise one-third of the project's participants. The results of the proposed research will be useful in planning for emergencies following dam or levee failure and the development of strategies for the mitigation of adverse ecological and morphological impacts.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Major Research Activities and Significant Results

  1. Experiments and numerical modeling were conducted to quantify the failure process of an overtopped, homogenous non-compacted levee. Water-surface velocity distributions, breach shape evolution, breach outflow, and time series of the water-surface elevations at breach location were measured using a variety of techniques. Erodibility coefficients in both vertical and horizontal directions were determined from the experimental results and the corresponding bed-load transport formulas were proposed.
  2. Significant progress was made on the experimental study of levee breach by overtopping and piping. A new methodology was developed for tracking levee breach evolution from video images of embedded tracers released by embankment erosion.
  3. Nine large- and eight small-scale experiments were successfully conducted and produced data on the effects of soil composition, levee height, and compaction energy on breach processes and the resulting flood. A field-scale test was done in Pakistan.
  4. After the October 2015 flood in South Carolina, the team gathered time-sensitive data on 14 failed/compromised small dams and embankments. The data was analyzed, soil samples tested, and new relationships were developed for modeling breach dimensions. The results have been published in the Journal of Hydraulic Engineering as a case study paper.
  5. A new dimensionless equation was developed for a correction factor for the outflow discharge. The factor may be used to correct the predicted outflow discharge from one-dimensional models and to include the effect of the two-dimensional flow field of the levee breach problem. 
  6. Detailed 3-D velocity and turbulence data on a laboratory model of levee breach was collected using a micro ADV. Researchers at the National Center for Computational Hydroscience and Engineering at the University of Mississipi have utilized these data for model validation. Comparisons between experimental measurements and model results have shown good agreements. The entire data set is available at our website, www.pire.ce.sc.edu.
  7. The drag and added-mass coefficients were estimated for sandbags and the values of the added-mass coefficient were compared to those for solid spheres.
  8. Velocity profiles in a dam-break experiment were measured using ultrasonic Doppler velocity profiler (UVP). To our knowledge, velocity profiles in a dam-break flow have not been measured earlier, except once. The data collected in the present study will be useful in validating vertical structure resolving numerical models of unsteady open channel flow.
  9. Using a set of UVP, the flow field around building clusters were measured and the free-surface velocity field was obtained.. The data is useful for validating 2D depth-averaged and 3D free surface flow models. The data has been uploaded to www.pire.ce.sc.edu.
  10. Experiments were conducted and a numerical model was developed for tracking sand-bag motion in a fixed-bed flume. The results demonstrate that a variable-drag approach is better suited for computing the trajectory and velocity of sandbags.
  11. Experiments were conducted on 3D partial-breach dam-break flow.  The comprehensive data set will be useful for validating 3D models of unsteady free surface flows.
  12. 3D numerical modeling of dam-break flow was conducted using a CFD solver. The results show that Large Eddy Simulation (LES) model for turbulence closure provide satisfactory prediction of experimental results.

BROADER IMPACT

  1. The project allowed research collaboration and student excahnge between the USA and Belgium, Egypt, Pakistan, New Zealand, and Puerto Rico.
  2. The project organized five workshops held in Puerto Rico, Egypt, Belgium, New Zealand and Columbia, South Carolina and were attended by graduate students, experts from academia and practice, advisory committee members, and invited speakers.
  3. The project provided 30-day research-abroad experience to 48 undergraduate students. A female graduate student spent six weeks at our partner institution in Belgium. The collaboration resulted in two conference papers and presentations.
  4. 11 students visited the New Orleans levee breach sites and US Army Corps of Engineers Laboratory.
  5. Four minority high school students participated in summer research programs.
  6. Early-career faculty members from USC and minortiy-serving institutions benefited from participation in the project.
  7. During the 2016 and 2017 Engineering Week at USC, demonstration of levee-breach experiments by overtopping was done for several hundred visiting parents and students.
  8. The graduate course Fluid Transients was offered by the PI to 17 students at USC, 8 in Cairo University, and 22 at the Centre of Excellence in Water Resources Engineering (CEWRE), Pakistan during Spring, 2010.
  9. The PI delivered a lecture at the Annual Congress of the Environmental and Water Resources Institute, ASCE, for accepting the Hunter Rouse Hydraulic Engineering Award in 2008 (The most prestigious ASCE award for Water Resources). A paper based on this presentation was published in the Journal of Hydraulic Engineering. This paper was the top-downloaded paper for the journal in 2011.
  10. The project activities gained local and national attention in the following news outlets:
  • The State, the leading newspaper of Columbia, South Carolina
  • Fox Business http://www.foxbusiness.com/story/americas-infrastructure/dams-levees/prevent-katrina-style-flooding/#
  • University of South Carolina (USC) Times
  • University of South Carolina (USC) Breakthrough (research magazine).
